title: A Detailed Protocol for Large-scale Recombinant Expression and Validation of Human FGFR2 with Its Transmembrane and Extracellular Domains in Escherichia coli
procedures: Part I: Large Scale Expression and Purification of FGFR2’s Extracellular and Transmembrane Domains Synthesizing FGFR2 ECD + TM construct via polymerase incomplete primer extension (PIPE) cloningPolymerase Incomplete Primer Extension (PIPE) cloning is a more efficient alternative to cloning with restriction and ligation enzymes. Instead of adding flanking restriction sites and using restriction enzymes to digest the sites followed by phosphorylation and ligation, PIPE cloning uses ligation independent cloning from annealing overhanging PCR ends and requires less time and components. Overhangs are added on to the sequences by using one half of the primers for the FGFR sequence and another half for the vector. The single-stranded overhangs that are now flanking the FGFR sequences are complementary to the vector sequence. As a result, by combining the two with subsequent transformation, a recombinant plasmid is formed (Klock and Lesley, 2009). PCRPrepare the PCR reaction according to the instructions specified by the Phusion® High-Fidelity PCR kit using primers for generating the FGFR2 ECD + TM (31-406) construct.Add 6% DMSO to each reaction along with the proper PCR components for 25 μl reactions for the FGFR2 and vector pSpeedET + Maltose Binding Protein (MBP).PCR Reaction components for a 25 μl reaction are: FGFR/pSpeedET + MBP vector template: 20 ng eachPhusion Hi Fidelity buffer: 5 μlPhusion Hi Fidelity DNA polymerase: 0.25 μl0.2 μM dNTP (0.5 μl of 10 mM dNTP)0.5 μM forward and reverse primers (1.25 μl of 10 μM stocks)6% DMSO: 1.5 μl of DMSOType 1 nuclease-free water: add to a total volume of 25 μlAdjust the settings on the thermocycler to: 98 °C for 6 min;Followed by a cycle of 35 times with the settings 98 °C for 30 s; 50 °C for 30 s;72 °C for 2 min;Finally 72 °C for 10 min followed by a 4 °C holding period.

During this time, the overhangs of the FGFR sequences and the vector (with MBP) will anneal together creating a recombinant plasmid with the FGFR sequence and maltose binding protein. MBP was used as a fusion tag to increase the solubility of the construct and for protein identification during Western blot analysis. Because the FGFR sequences contain the hydrophobic transmembrane domain and the goal was to preserve the integrity of the transmembrane domain throughout expression studies, it was essential to use MBP (Figures 1 and 2).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190602/20190602192732_8205.jpgFigure 1. Process of polymerase incomplete primer extension (PIPE) cloningTransformation for cloning–Immediately after the PIPE annealing, transfer into E. coli DH5α cells for cloningThaw 1 vial of DH5α competent cells on ice. Add 2 μl of the PIPE reaction to the cells and incubate on ice for 10 min. Heat shock the cells at 42 °C for 30 s and place the cells back on ice for 2 min. Add 500 μl of SOC recovery media (at RT) to the cells and place them in a 37 °C shaker for one hour. Spread 100 μl of the transformation on LB + kanamycin plates and incubate them at 37 °C overnight. Kanamycin final concentration is at 50 μg/ml.

Colony polymerase chain reaction, DNA extraction, and sequencing–Verify success of PIPE cloning by size and sequence using colony PCR and sequencingUse a pipette tip to pick a colony and resuspend it in 13.7 μl of nuclease-free water (the volume of water needed for a 25 μl PCR reaction).Add 13.7 μl water, 2.5 μl of 2.5 mM dNTPs, 2.5 μl of 2 mM forward primer, 2.5 μl of 2 μM reverse primer, 0.3 μl e2TAK polymerase (Takara Bio), and 5 μl polymerase 5x Buffer. The thermocycler conditions are as follows: 94 °C for 6 min followed by 35 cycles of 94 °C for 30 s, 50 °C for 30 s, and 72 °C for 2 min, and finally 72 °C for 10 min followed by a 4 °C holding period.Run on a 1% agarose gel to confirm the size of the expected insert.Grow the selected colonies in 3 ml LB + kanamycin overnight at 37 °C in a shaker at 230 rpm in 5 ml culture tubes.Isolate the recombinant plasmid using the General Electric Healthcare illustra plasmidPrep Mini Spin Kit.Determine the presence and accuracy of the construct by sequencing.Verify the sequence is correct by analysis with ApE program for nucleotide analysis and BLASTn comparison.Large scale expression of the FGFR2 constructTransformation and inoculation for protein expression in Lemo21 DE3 cellsUsing the protocol as specified from above (Step A2), positively select using LB + kanamycin agar plates.Chose a colony and grow overnight between 12 h and 16 h in 100 ml of LB with 50 μg/ml kanamycin + 25 μg/ml chloramphenicol. After 16 h, prepare the inoculation: 100 ml overnight culture, 100 μg/ml kanamycin, 50 μg/ml chloramphenicol, 0.5 mM L-rhamnose, and 2 mM of MgSO4. Note: The concentrations of the reagents are based on a volume of 1,000 ml of Terrific Broth (TB).

Place the inoculated TB culture and antibiotics into the shaker at 37 °C. Monitor the OD600 as it approaches 0.6. Once the culture reaches an OD600 of 0.4-0.5, cool the cells to 18 °C in the shaker to slow the growth of cells. Note: OD should be checked every 10 min. The bacterial culture reaches OD = 0.6 after 30-45 min. Take 1 ml of each construct culture to serve as a negative control for later experiments. In addition, take a glycerol stock (50 μl of 50% glycerol in ddH2O and 50 μl of culture) for archival purposes. Store the glycerol stock at -80 °C. The glycerol should be sterile.Add isopropyl beta-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) at a 0.1 mM final concentration to each culture to induce expression.Incubate the cells in the shaker at 18 °C overnight at 230 rpm.The next day, harvest the cells as followed: centrifuge the culture at 4 °C at 4,000 x g for 10 min.Discard the supernatant and wash the pellet by resuspending it in 100 ml 4 °C lysis buffer (Recipe 1). Centrifuge again at 4,000 x g for 10 min and discard the lysis buffer. Lysing cellsResuspend the post induction Lemo21 cell in 40 ml lysis buffer by vortexing and pipetting up and down to ensure homogeneity in a 50 ml conical tube. This must all be done on ice.Add 1 μl of 2000 U/ml DNase I, 1 μM CaCl2, and protease inhibitors (1 mM benzamidine, 1 mM PMSF, 1 μM E-64, 0.5 mM TCEP, 1 μM pepstatin, and 1 μM bestatin) to lysis buffer prior to lysis by sonication. Sonicate the cells. Sonication conditions: 6 cycles; 1 cycle: 20 s sonication ON followed by 40 s OFF.

Following sonication, place the suspension in a heavy-duty centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 48,384 x g using a JA20 rotor for 30 min. Separate and store both supernatant and cell pellet at -80 °C.Note: Optional stopping point. Ideally, better if the procedure is continued. Detergent extractionPrepare a lysis buffer that includes 1% n-dodecyl β-D-maltoside (DDM) detergent.For every 100 μg of cell pellet or 100 μl of supernatant, add 500 μl of 1% detergent solution and resuspend along with PMSF.Invert the suspension continuously for 2 h at 4 °C.Centrifuge the suspension at 23,708 x g for 15 min at 4 °C.Separate the supernatant and the cell pellet and store both at -80 °C. (Both the cell pellet and supernatant should possess FGFR2, but the cell pellet should contain more).Running samples through NuSep 8-16% Tris-Glycine Gels via polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) to determine if the protein of interest is presentResuspend the pellet in 300 μl MilliQ water and 100 μl of 4x loading dye with β-mercaptoethanol (BME) while 100 μl of the same loading dye was added to the 300 μl supernatant/portion of cell pellet. Centrifuge at 23,708 x g for 10 min in preparation for loading into a polyacrylamide gel. Note: Steps C1 and C2 are to ensure that the loaded sample is not too viscous for electrophoresis. Load the samples (20 μl per well) along with a ladder and run at 200 V for about 45 min.Run 2 gels so that one can be stained and the other can be used for Western blotting. Western blotting and antibody detection using anti-MBP monoclonal antibody HRP conjugatedWestern blot the gel of interest using the VWR Amresco® Buffers.Soak the Tris-glycine gel in Amresco rapid transfer buffer for 10 min. Use just enough buffer to cover the entire gel.

Soak the PVDF membrane for 30 s in methanol, then subsequently soak in water for 5 min, then finally soak in rapid transfer buffer until it no longer floats. Use just enough solution to cover the membrane.Assemble the Western block stack according to Amresco’s wet transfer protocol.Place the stack in the gel electrophoresis chamber with Amresco rapid transfer buffer and run at 75 V for 20 min. The rapid transfer buffer must be filled to the top of the chamber so that the stack is completely submerged in the buffer.Disassemble the stack and incubate the membrane in Amresco RapidBlockTM solution for 5 min.Incubate the PVDF membrane in 20 ml of blocking buffer for 1 h at room temperature. Incubate the PVDF Membrane in 20 ml of blocking buffer with 10 μl of anti-MBP monoclonal antibody (HRP Conjugated) from New England Biolabs overnight at 4 °C. The next day, use 25 ml of TBST (Recipe 2) to wash the PVDF membrane three times for 5 min each. Detect the presence of the protein using the KPL TMB Membrane Peroxidase Substrate System Kit. The volumes needed for the reaction to occur are listed in the kit’s instructions.  Refolding FGFR2 by dialysisWashing inclusion bodiesResuspend the pellets in 0.5% guanidinium-HCl (with just enough volume to get the pellets resuspended homogenously), and subsequently centrifuge at 4,000 x g for 20 min at 4 °C. After washing, the inclusion bodies should have a colorless appearance.Solubilization and denaturation of FGFR recombinant proteinDenature and solubilize the original inclusion bodies in 10 ml dialysis solution #1 (Recipe 3).To facilitate solubilization, warm the cell pellet and dialysis solution mixture to 40 °C temporarily in a water bath followed by gentle vortexing. The solution should be colorless and clear. Incubate the mixture prior to dialysis for 30-40 min at 40 °C.

Assembly of apparatus and incubationLoad the solubilized inclusion bodies in the dialysis solution #1 into a snakeskin membrane with clips.Suspend the filled membrane in a container with 700 ml dialysis solution #2 (Recipe 4).Place the apparatus in the cold room (4 °C) with gentle constant stirring using a magnetic stir bar overnight.The next day, place the sample from the snakeskin into heavy-duty centrifuge tubes and centrifuge at 48,384 x g for 30 min. Separate the pellet and supernatant and store at -80 °C. The protein of interest is in the supernatant.Purification and functionality testing via heparin binding chromatographyTo test isolate and begin testing the functionality of FGFR2, use the 1 ml HiTrapTM Heparin Affinity Chromatography column (GE Healthcare) with a syringe pump.Note: GE Healthcare provides instructions for how to use the column. The following is additional details for this procedure.Load 10 column volumes (CVs) of binding buffer (Recipe 5) onto the column with a syringe to equilibrate the column at a rate of 1 ml/min. 1 CV = 1 mlSyringe filter the FGFR2 supernatant from dialysis to prevent clogging and load it onto the column. Note: Make sure no air bubbles get into the column. Load the FGFR2 Supernatant unto the column.Wash the column of any debris with 5 CVs of binding buffer. Run 10 CVs of elution buffer (Recipe 6). Use sterile 1.5 ml centrifuge tubes to collect all flow through, wash, and elution fractions. The rate of loading and running is at 1 ml/min. The volume of each fraction should be 1 ml. 1 CV = 1 ml.Run a PAGE and Western Blot analysis to confirm FGFR2 isolation. For Western blotting, use the anti-MBP HRP-conjugated antibody from New England Biolabs to detect FGFR2 (Figure 3).

Run size exclusion chromatography (SEC) of the purified FGFR2 combined with FGF1, heparin, and FGFR2 to verify dimerization (Figure 4). Follow by Western blotting of the SEC elution fractions with the anti-MBP antibody to identify the size of the eluted complex.Notes: The first step in testing functionality is to determine whether or not FGFR2 can bind to heparin and FGF1. This step is essential since heparin and FGF1 binding is a necessary step to ternary complex formation and dimerization. To do this, repeat Procedure F above along with loading 1 ml of FGF1’s elution from SEC, followed by 10 CVs (10 ml) of binding buffer between Steps F2 and F3. Critical notes have been included throughout the protocol at important steps. Overall, this is a lengthy procedure with few stopping points. As an additional note, we have included how we express, isolate and purify FGF1 to test for FGFR2 functionality.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190602/20190602192829_6115.jpgFigure 3. Western blot shows elution of FGFR2 + MBP Construct (red rectangle) from HiTrap heparin affinity chromatography demonstrating recombinant protein’s ability to bind to heparin. Lane 1: Protein standard. Lanes 2-3: Wash fractions. Lanes 4-5: Elution fraction.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190602/20190602192857_0176.jpgFigure 4. Size exclusion chromatography profile. Elution fractions are in red and range from A9-12, followed by B12-B7. Elution fractions A11 and A12 correspond to inactive FGFR2 containing the ECD + TM domains in dimers in micelles. Elution fraction B11 corresponds to FGFR2 containing the ECD + TM domains. Elution fractions B11-B8 corresponds to FGF1. Each elution fraction has a volume of 1 ml. Part II: FGF1 Expression and PurificationFGF1 expressionTransform DH5α cells using the FGF1 expression vector in pMCSG7 from the DNASU plasmid repository. To clone it, use the same procedure as detailed under Step A2 but use carbenicillin instead of kanamycin as the selection marker.

Grow a colony in 3 ml of LB with 100 μg/ml carbenicillin overnight. Isolate DNA from the culture using the GE Healthcare illustra plasmidPrep Mini Spin Kit. Confirm FGF1 sequence using T7 forward and reverse primers. Large scale expressionTransform the FGF1 expression plasmid into competent E. coli Lemo21 (DE3) cells and positively select with carbenicillin. Pick a colony and grow in 100 ml LB with chloramphenicol and carbenicillin overnight. The next day, use this culture to inoculate 1,000 ml of TB with 100 μg/ml carbenicillin, 50 μg/ml chloramphenicol, 0.5 mM rhamnose, and 2 mM of MgSO4 following Steps B1c above. Continue to cell harvesting, cell lysis by sonication and ultra-centrifugation as discussed above in Step B2, all at 4 °C. The protein will be in the supernatant.FGF1 PurificationNote: Purify the FGF1 using a 1 ml HiTrapTM Column (GE Healthcare) with a syringe. Fill the syringe with 1 ml of binding buffer which is the same lysis buffer used for the large-scale expression of FGFR2. Making sure the air bubbles are out of the syringe, run the same lysis buffer through the column at a rate of 1 ml/min. Before reaching the end of the syringe, it was refilled with binding buffer, and again pushed through the syringe. This was done with 9 more CVs to equilibrate the column. Run the entire FGF1 sample (supernatant from ultracentrifugation) through the column using the syringe. Wash column with 10 CVs (10 ml total) of lysis buffer to elute any contaminating proteins that may have non-specifically bound to FGF1 and heparin. Elute FGF1 with elution buffer (Recipe 7).

Determine the success of purification by PAGE and Western blot analysis as discussed above under Procedure C and Procedure D, but instead of using an anti-MBP antibody (HRP conjugated), an anti-His antibody (HRP conjugated) was used from Pierce. Use size exclusion chromatography (SEC) to further purify the protein. Load 2 ml of the elution onto the column (this was the maximum volume allowed and its concentration was determined to be acceptable to subsequent functionality experiments with FGFR: 1.756 μg/ml). The running buffer (Recipe 8) used for size exclusion chromatography (SEC) was 25 mM HEPES, 0.1% DDM, and 150 mM NaCl at pH 7.5.
